abstract: <jats:p>During a DNA barcoding campaign of leaf-mining Gracillariidae from the Asian part of Russia, a new species of<jats:italic>Phyllonorycter</jats:italic>Hübner, feeding on the Siberian pea shrub,<jats:italic>Caraganaarborescens</jats:italic>Lam. (Fabaceae) was discovered in Siberia. Here, this taxon is described as<jats:italic>Phyllonorycterivani</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold>Among Fabaceae-feeding<jats:italic>Phyllonorycter</jats:italic>, so far only<jats:italic>P.caraganella</jats:italic>(Ermolaev) has been known to develop on<jats:italic>Caragana</jats:italic>.<jats:italic>Phyllonorycterivani</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>P.caraganella</jats:italic>show a large divergence in morphology (external and male genitalia) and barcode region of the mtDNA-COI gene (8.6%). They feed on different host plants species and have different ranges in Russia. We show that DNA barcode data weakly supports the Fabaceae-feeding species groups. In addition, we show that morphologically (strongly) and genetically (weakly),<jats:italic>P.ivani</jats:italic>has affinity to the<jats:italic>haasi</jats:italic>species group, a West Palearctic group with asymmetrical male genitalia.</jats:p>
title: New species of leaf-mining Phyllonorycter (Lepidoptera Gracillariidae) from Siberia feeding on Caragana (Fabaceae)
